name: Hydrogen
displayName: Hydrogen is the most abundant chemical substance in the Universe, constituting roughly 75% of all baryonic mass.
description: Hydrogen is the chemical element with the symbol H and atomic number 1.

name: Lithium
displayName: It is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal.
description: Lithium is a chemical element with the symbol Li and atomic number 3.

name: Sodium
displayName: It is a soft, silvery-white, highly reactive metal.
description: Sodium is a chemical element with the symbol Na and atomic number 11.

name: Potassium
displayName: Potassium is a silvery-white metal that is soft enough to be cut with a knife with little force.
description: Potassium is a chemical element with the symbol K and atomic number 19.

name: Caesium
displayName: Caesium has physical and chemical properties similar to those of rubidium and potassium.
description: Caesium is a chemical element with the symbol Cs and atomic number 55.

name: Mercury
displayName: It is commonly known as quicksilver and was formerly named hydrargyrum.
description: Mercury is a chemical element with the symbol Hg and atomic number 80.

name: Thallium
displayName: It is a gray post-transition metal that is not found free in nature.
description: Thallium is a chemical element with the symbol Tl and atomic number 81.

name: Lead
displayName: Lead is soft and malleable, and also has a relatively low melting point.
description: Lead is a chemical element with the symbol Pb (from the Latin plumbum) and atomic number 82.

name: Bismuth
displayName: Elemental bismuth may occur naturally, although its sulfide and oxide form important commercial ores.
description: Bismuth is a chemical element with the symbol Bi and atomic number 83.

name: Polonium
displayName: Polonium was named after Marie Curie's homeland of Poland.
description: Polonium is a chemical element with the symbol Po and atomic number 84.

name: Astatine
displayName: The bulk properties of astatine are not known with any certainty.
description: Astatine is a radioactive chemical element with the symbol At and atomic number 85.
